natural problem: Find the angle between the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ in degrees.
natural solution: If $\theta$ is the angle between the vectors, then \[\cos \theta = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{(2)(-1) + (-1)(1) + (1)(0)}{\sqrt{6} \cdot \sqrt{2}} = \frac{-3}{2 \sqrt{3}} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.\]Hence, $\theta = \boxed{150^\circ}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v1 v2 :: "real^3" and angle :: real
assumes h0 : "v1 = vector [2, -1, 1]"
and h1 : "v2 = vector [-1, 1, 0]"
and h2 : "angle = arccos ((v1 \<bullet> v2) / (norm v1 * norm v2))"
shows  "180 * angle / pi = 150"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 If $\theta$ is the angle between the vectors, then \[\cos \theta = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{(2)(-1) + (-1)(1) + (1)(0)}{\sqrt{6} \cdot \sqrt{2}} = \frac{-3}{2 \sqrt{3}} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.\]Hence, $\theta = \boxed{150^\circ}.$
 *)

and h2 : "angle = arccos ((v1 \<bullet> v2) / (norm v1 * norm v2))"

 *)
